noun.description: A thing of little value or importance.
examples: we needn't trouble the headmaster over such trifles

noun.description: A cold dessert of sponge cake and fruit covered with layers of custard, jelly, and cream.

verb.description: Treat (someone or something) without seriousness or respect.
examples: he is not a man to be trifled with
men who trifle with women's affections
we will not trifle—life is too short

phrases: his methods are a trifle eccentric
The trip was made a trifle bit easy for him since he was accompanying his parents to various areas, where all three worked in their respective area.
But I know the chances of being able to actually go somewhere are a trifle slim, seeing as I've left it a bit late and all…
Perhaps it would be a trifle rash to suggest that Australian sport has gone into terminal decline.
But afterwards, the fields seemed a bit larger, the houses a trifle more substantial, the roads wider.
origin: Middle English (also denoting an idle story told to deceive or amuse): from Old French trufle, by-form of trufe deceit, of unknown origin. The verb derives from Old French truffler mock, deceive.
